topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Port Arbitration

body.p: Port arbitration resolves contention when multiple ingress ports target the same egress port. Port arbitration is done independently by each port on the egress side of the Switch. Each port has a dedicated port arbiter which uses either a Fixed Round Robin arbitration mode (FRR) or a Dynamically Programmable Weighted Round Robin (WRR) arbitration mode in order to select the next ingress port for transfer. By default, the port arbitration for all ports is programmed to use FRR. In this case the port implements a round-robin scheme in which all ingress ports are weighted equally among all incoming requests from the ingress ports on a per TLP basis.

FRR is generally selected when all ingress ports are the same. For example, all ingress ports have the same port width, bandwidth requirements, and latency requirements. If some subset of ports has different requirements, then WRR arbitration is preferred. Figure 1 illustrates the differences between FRR and WRR.

For example, if one of the ingress ports is wider and requires higher bandwidth than the others, then it may be beneficial to use WRR. If a system uses FRR with 8 x4 Endpoints and a x16 Expansion port, then the x16 port is throttled to an effective port width of x4. Note also that if the egress port is not oversubscribed, then either arbitration mode will regress to transmit the first arrival TLP. If multiple ports have TLPs arriving at the same time, then the transmission order is effectively random.
WRR is implemented using a MRPC command to configure the weights for the port arbiter. See MRPC_RESERVE0 Port Arbitration Command for more information on using MRPC to configure the port arbitration.
body.note: The implementation of WRR in Switchtec is different from the WRR defined in the PCIe base spec 4.0 spec for arbitrating between VCs. Switchtec WRR adds up the weights of each port on the table and uses them as a weighting number.

section.title: Using WRR
section.p: When using WRR several considerations need to be taken in order to properly select and optimize the weighting scheme:

li.p: An ingress port cannot be granted more than its available bandwidth.
For example, if a x2 port is sending TLPs towards a x16, it cannot be programmed for more than 12.5 % of the sum of all weights of participating ingress ports towards that egress port.

There are limitations on the maximum weight that can be programmed for an ingress port into the arbiter, and the limitation depends upon the ingress port's effective rate and the egress port's effective rate. Any weights calculated based on desired BW must take into account these restrictions and the weights adjusted and programmed accordingly. It is possible that the calculation can deviate from a target bandwidth, but will exactly meet the programmed weight calculation. The restrictions are given in Table 1:

table.title: Restrictions on weight allocation based on bifurcation

li.p: Weights on unused ports and ports in other partitions must be set to 1. This is done to prevent a mis-routed TLP from an ingress port from never moving through the switch and causing a deadlock.
Weights for low data rate ports (i.e. Management hosts or BMCs) should be set to 1.
The effective bandwidth contribution of an ingress port to a egress port is normally calculated as
li.codeblock: (Egress Port BW) * (X/Y) X is the weight of the ingress port Y is the total of all of the weights of ingress ports requesting to an egress port
li.p: It is however important to use the sum total of “active” (i.e “plugged in” ports) in determining the total weight ‘Y’ of all the requesting ingress ports. Ports with no meaningful bandwidth (low speed IO) can also be considered "not active" in this calculation.

Example: if there are 24 ingress ports requesting to an egress port, but 2 of the ingress ports are inactive (i.e. empty), then one must only sum the weights of 22 of the active ports in calculating ‘Y’
The weights for each egress port can by dynamically updated via MRPC in response to system topology changes

section.title: Bandwidth calculation examples
section.p: Some bandwidth calculation examples have been provided below that illustrate the rules stated above.

example.title: Example 1a
example.p: We need to have four x4 ingress ports contribute a total of 500MB/sec and a single x16 ingress port contribute a total of 15.5GB/sec to an egress x16 port (total bandwidth of 16GB).

li.p: We first calculate the desired weights. The ratio of bandwidths for the x4 ports versus the x16 is 0.5:15.5. Since we have 4 x4s, then the desired weight ratio becomes 0.5 : (15.5 * 4) or 1 : 124.

Now we apply the restrictions on weights. We see that the desired x4 weight is less than the maximum programmable x4 weight of 10, and the x16 weight is also within the maximum programmable weight of 255, so we need not perform any weight adjustments.
Now we perform bandwidth calculations to verify that we have the desired BW ratios.
We now calculate the sum total of all weights (Y) as Y = (4 * 1) + 124 = 128.

example.p: Each x4 ingress port will contribute (x4 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 1/128 * 16 = 0.125G = 125MB/sec. Therefore the four x4s will contribute a total of 125 * 4 = 500MB/sec.
The x16 ingress port will contribute (x16 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 124/128 * 16 = 15.5GB/sec.

example.title: Example 1b
example.p: We need to have four x4 ingress ports contribute a total of 15.5GB/sec and a single x16 ingress port contribute 500MB/sec to an egress x16 port (total bandwidth of 16GB/sec).

li.p: We first calculate the desired weights. The ratio of bandwidths for the x4 ports versus the x16 is 15.5:0.5. Since we have 4 x4s, then the desired weight ratio becomes 15.5:(0.5 * 4) or 31 : 4.

Now we apply the restrictions on weights. We see that the desired x4 weight of 31 is more than the maximum programmable x4 weight of 10, and we therefore need to perform a weight adjustment on the x4 weights.
We select the x4 and x16 weights that give a ratio close to 31:4, and for this example we select the x4 weight as 8, and the corresponding x16 weight as 1, making the adjusted weight ratio 8:1.
Now we perform bandwidth calculations to verify that we have the desired BW ratios.
We now calculate the sum total of all weights (Y) as Y = (4 * 8) + 1 = 33.

example.p: Each x4 ingress port will contribute (x4 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 8/33 * 16 = 3.878GB/sec. All four x4 ports therefore will contribute 3.878GB * 4 = 15.52GB/sec.
The x16 ingress port will contribute (x16 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 1/33 * 16 = 485MB/sec.

example.title: Example 2a
example.p: We need to have 24 x2 ingress ports contribute a total of 12GB/sec and a single x8 ingress port contribute 4GB/sec to an egress x16 port (total bandwidth of 16GB/sec).

li.p: First we calculate the desired weights. The ratio of bandwidths for the x2 ports versus the x8 is 12:4. Since we have 24 x2s, then the desired weight ratio becomes 12:(4 * 24) or 1:8.

Now we apply the restrictions on weights. We see that the desired x2 weight is less than the maximum programmable x2 weight of 5, and the x8 weight is also within the maximum programmable weight of 24, so we need not perform any weight adjustments
Now we perform bandwidth calculations to verify that we have the desired BW ratios.
We now calculate the sum total of all weights (Y) as Y = (24 * 1) + 8 = 32.

example.p: Each x2 ingress port will contribute (x2 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 1/32 * 16 = 500MB/sec. All 24 x2 ports therefore will contribute 24 * 500MB/sec = 12GB/sec
The x8 ingress port will contribute (x8 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 8/32 * 16 = 4GB/sec.

example.title: Example 2b
example.p: For the above system from Example (2a), calculate the bandwidth contributions from the ingress ports if 4 x2 ingress ports were to become “inactive”.

li.p: We first adjust (Y) as Y = ((24 - 4) * 1) + 8 = 28
We now calculate the bandwidth contributions.

example.p: Each x2 ingress port will contribute (x2 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 1/28 * 16 =~ 571MB/sec.
The 20 active x2 ports therefore will contribute a total of (20 * 571MB/sec) =~ 11.42GB/sec
The x8 ingress port will contribute (x8 weight/(Y)) * 16GB/sec = 8/28 * 16GB/sec =~ 4.57GB/sec.
